question.body: Which type of ion channel is opened when acetylcholine binds to an inhibitory muscarinic receptor?

response.feedback: Correct. As the potassium ions leave the cell it hyperpolarized the membrane, making it less likely to initiate an action potential to inhibit the post-synaptic cell.
Incorrect. As the sodium ions enter the cell that will depolarize and potentially initiate an action potential, thus stimulating not inhibiting the post-synaptic cell.
Incorrect. This ion would depolarize, but not in response to ACh at muscarinic, but other neurotransmitter such as GABA.
Incorrect. This voltage-gated ion channel will be involved in the action potential stimulating release of neurotransmitter.
Incorrect. This is not an ion typically involved in cell membrane potential.

question.body: If only a few molecules of neurotransmitter are released, which type of receptor would cause a potentially bigger but slower response in the post-synaptic cell?

multiple_choice.choice: a receptor linked to ion channel
a receptor linked to second messenger
a receptor on the cell surface

response.feedback: Incorrect. Either excitatory or inhibitory receptors will show this response.
Incorrect. Either excitatory or inhibitory receptors will show this response.
Correct. One neurotransmitter will only open one ion channel but stimulate the creation of many second messenger molecules within effector cell.
Incorrect. All receptors are on the post-synaptic cell membrane.
